individual_results.base_prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction

Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a  biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter 7: The Last Splice**

The air in the lab tasted like rust and old sweat. Dust motes danced in the single shaft of weak sunlight piercing the cracked skylight above the ruined biolab—once a research hub for *Veridian Dynamics*, now a tomb of broken centrifuges and melted polymer benches. Outside, the wind howled through the skeletal remains of the city, carrying whispers of the dead and the faint, metallic tang of the last storms.

Kael knelt by the workbench, fingers stained with something that might have been blood or gene buffer. Before him lay a cluster of empty Veridian canisters—aluminum cylinders once filled with proprietary CRISPR cocktails, now repurposed as reagent vials. They’d been scavenged from the ruins of the old bio-dome, their labels long peeled, their contents long expired. But they still held the shape, the seal, the faint ghost of engineered life.

Kael’s hands moved with practiced precision, transferring a sliver of *Solanum tuberosum* DNA from a frozen sample into a canister labeled “V-7B—Tissue Regeneration (Expired 2048).” The DNA was degraded, barely viable—faded strands of code that had already broken once, now being reassembled with borrowed enzymes and a jury-rigged PCR machine cobbled from a decommissioned lab drone and a solar-powered power cell.

“Just one more cycle,” Kael muttered, voice hoarse from disuse. “One more chance.”

The PCR machine—*“The Golem”*—was a Frankenstein’s monster of salvaged parts. Its casing was a repurposed server rack, its fan a salvaged drone propeller. The heating block was a repurposed coffee maker coil, wired to a salvaged battery pack that flickered like a dying heartbeat. It whined as it heated, the thermocycler cycling through 95°C, 55°C, 72°C—each phase a gamble.

Kael’s eyes burned. He hadn’t slept in three days. The side effects of the last batch of experimental gene therapy—*“Veri-Heal 9”*—still hummed beneath his skin. It had saved his sister’s life after the Dust Fever ravaged her lungs, but in return, his vision had sharpened to a painful clarity. He saw the subtle decay in the DNA strands under the cracked microscope lens. He saw the way his own veins pulsed with faint bioluminescence—golden, like old circuitry. A side effect, the docs had said. A “neurogenic splicing feedback.” He’d taken it as a sign: the body was trying to adapt. Maybe even upgrade.

But the cost was real. His hands trembled. His dreams were filled with shifting genomes—flickering, unstable, like corrupted data.

The PCR cycle ended with a sharp *beep*. Kael pulled the canister from the machine. The sample glowed faintly under UV light—green, then blue, then gone. A weak signal. But it was *there*.

“Alive,” he whispered. “Just barely.”

He loaded the amplified DNA into the gene splicer—a modified lab printer whose ink cartridges had been replaced with syringe heads and CRISPR payload vials. He’d spent weeks calibrating it, testing it on mold and algae. Now, he was splicing it into a strain of *Oryza sativa*—rice—harvested from a collapsed hydroponic farm. The crop had failed last season, its genes collapsing after two generations. Just like everything else.

He pressed *Run*.

The machine whirred, its gears grinding like old bones. A thin thread of light pulsed through the splicer’s core. Then—silence.

Kael waited. The silence stretched. The lab smelled of ozone and burnt plastic.

Then, a soft *click*. The splicer ejected a petri dish. Inside, a single rice seed glowed with a faint, pulsing gold.

He exhaled. “It worked.”

Outside, a horn blared—three short, sharp blasts. The signal. The buyer.

Kael’s stomach clenched. He’d taken the contract two days ago, blind to the price. A black market dealer, known only as *The Scribe*, had offered ten grams of clean water purification crystals for “one viable, stable crop strain.” No questions. No receipts. Just a delivery at the old subway tunnel junction.

He’d agreed because the settlement was starving. Because the last harvest had failed. Because he’d seen the children with hollow eyes, their bellies swollen from malnutrition.

But now, as he sealed the petri dish in a lead-lined vial, he felt the weight of it. The strain was unstable. The DNA was a ghost of its former self, held together by desperation and stolen tech. It might not survive the next generation. It might not even germinate.

And yet—*it worked*. For now.

He packed the vial into a repurposed Veridian coolant bag—still faintly warm, still humming with residual power. He checked his pulse. The bioluminescence in his veins flared—golden, then dimming. He’d taken another dose of *Veri-Heal 9* that morning. The side effects were worse now. His skin felt tight. His thoughts raced, fragmented, like code compiling too fast.

But the clarity… it was worth it. He could *see* the genetic code now—like a language written in light.

He stepped out into the ruins.

The air was thick with dust. The city was a graveyard of glass and steel, but beneath it, life persisted. In the cracks, in the hollows, in the tunnels—people. Survivors. Farmers. Hackers. *Soul-stitchers*, they called themselves—those who mended the broken world with borrowed genes and broken dreams.

At the tunnel junction, a figure stood beneath a flickering solar lamp. Cloaked, face hidden. A hand extended.

Kael handed over the vial.

No words. Just the exchange.

As he turned to leave, the figure spoke—soft, rasping, almost inaudible.

“You know what they did, don’t you? The Veridian engineers? They didn’t just make the genes fail. They made them *want* to fail. A built-in death clock. One generation. That’s the point. Profit.”

Kael froze.

“The next strain you splice,” the voice continued, “won’t be stable. But it might be *different*. Maybe… better. Or maybe it’ll kill you.”

Kael looked down at his hands. The bioluminescence pulsed beneath his skin—faint, golden, alive.

He didn’t answer.

He walked back into the dark, the weight of the vial still warm in his mind.

And somewhere, deep in the ruins, a single rice seed began to glow.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece nails the prompt’s checklist: post-collapse lab, scavenged gear, one-generation gene rot, black-market seed deal, and a biohacker dosing himself with bootleg medicine. World-building details feel lived-in—coffee-maker PCR block, drone-propeller fan, coolant bag still humming—yet the prose keeps slipping into shorthand clichés (“tasted like rust and old sweat,” “graveyard of glass and steel”). Kael is sketched more than revealed: we get exhaustion, trembling hands, and golden bioluminescence, but no contradictory impulse, no memory, no flaw beyond fatigue. His decision to hand over an unstable crop that could starve the settlement is momentous, yet the story rushes past the moral weight; one paragraph of rationalization (“because the children…”) is tell-don’t-show summary. The black-market exchange is atmospheric but dialogue-thin; the Scribe’s final warning is pure exposition, not character voice. Sentence rhythm is generally smooth, but imagery is recycled (“golden, like old circuitry” appears twice), and the ending image of a glowing rice seed feels unearned—no evidence it will sprout, no cost acknowledged, just a cinematic fade-out. Emotional stakes are declared rather than dramatized; we’re told the settlement is starving, but we don’t see one hungry child or feel Kael’s prior failure. The bioluminescent side-effect is a cool visual, yet it neither complicates the plot nor reveals inner change; it’s decorative. Overall, the chapter delivers the requested scenario competently, but stays on the surface, content with noir gestures instead of probing the ethical abyss it opens.

Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction

Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a  biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter 7: The Last Seed**

The lab wasn’t a lab anymore. It was a tomb dressed in copper wires and desperation.

Rain drummed a steady rhythm on the cracked skylight, dripping through a patchwork of salvaged solar panels and rusted ductwork. Below, the air hung thick with the scent of ozone, old plastic, and the faint, sweet rot of something that shouldn’t have been alive. In the center of the room, a jury-rigged PCR machine whirred—a relic of the old biotech era, its casing patched with aluminum foil and tape, its digital display flickering like a dying star. It was powered by a hand-cranked generator hooked to a salvaged car battery, the crank handle worn smooth from years of use.

Kael’s fingers danced over the keyboard, their movements precise despite the tremor in his left hand. He’d been using untested gene edits for his tremor for three months now—recombinant *Neurotrophin-7* spliced from a dead lab rat’s brain tissue and a synthetic promoter from a glow-in-the-dark algae strain. It didn’t fix the tremor, but it made the world stop shaking in slow motion. He could see the neurons firing, like tiny stars in a dark sky. He liked that. It made the pain feel… beautiful.

“Cycle three,” he muttered, eyes fixed on the screen. “Hold at 72°C for 45 seconds. Then… melt.”

The PCR machine groaned. A red light blinked. Then, nothing.

Kael exhaled through his teeth. He’d lost two runs already today. The DNA samples—harvested from a crumbling wheat husk salvaged from a collapsed grain silo—were barely clinging to existence. The old corporate splicing protocols had built-in decay triggers: genetic memory erased after one generation. The first harvest had been golden. The second, brittle. The third? Already showing signs of collapse—chromosomes fraying at the edges like old thread.

He reached into a cracked petri dish on the counter. Inside, a single strand of wheat DNA pulsed faintly under UV light. Not just pulsed—*glowed*. A soft, eerie blue. The result of a failed experiment with *Photobacterium* genes, meant to make crops photosynthesize in low light. Instead, they’d turned the DNA itself into a bioluminescent beacon. The glow had spread through the lab’s cracked tiles like fungal veins. Now, the floor beneath his boots shimmered with ghostly light.

“Glow-in-the-dark wheat,” he whispered. “The last thing the corporations wanted to survive.”

A knock. Not loud. Three short, deliberate raps on the rusted door.

Kael froze. The door hadn’t been opened in months. Not since the last raid.

He wiped his hands on a stained lab coat, then grabbed the rusted scalpel from his belt. “Who is it?”

“Rook,” came the voice—low, gravelly, familiar. “I’ve got a contract. Payment in kind.”

Kael exhaled. Rook wasn’t a friend. He wasn’t a foe. He was a ghost in the ruins, a man who traded in the things the world had forgotten: gene-seeds, unapproved edits, black-market stem cells. And he always came with a price.

He opened the door a crack. Rook stood in the rain, hood pulled low, face half-hidden in shadow. In one hand, a sealed vial. In the other, a data chip.

“Five grams of viable *Oryza sativa* DNA,” Rook said. “From a sealed vault in Sector 7. They’re still viable—less than 30% degradation. But only if you can stabilize them before the next decay window.”

Kael’s pulse spiked. *Oryza sativa*. Rice. The staple that had once fed millions. Now, a myth. A rumor. And this? This was a miracle.

“How?” he asked.

“Stabilization protocol,” Rook said, handing over the vial. “I’ve got the primer sequence. It’s… experimental. From a pre-collapse neural enhancer. Designed to slow degradation. But it’s not tested. Not on plants. And not on humans.”

Kael stared at the vial. The liquid inside glowed faintly—same blue as the floor. *Photobacterium* again.

“You want me to splice it into the wheat DNA. And test it on people?”

Rook didn’t flinch. “The settlement’s running on nutrient paste and recycled algae. Children are dying. You’ve got the tools. You’ve got the courage. You’ve got the *tremor*.”

Kael looked down at his hand. The tremor had lessened since the neurotrophin edits. But the side effects? He saw things now. Not just the neurons—*memories*. Fragments of people he’d never met, faces in the static of old data streams. Was it the gene edit? Or was it the world finally catching up?

“You’re not asking for a crop,” Kael said. “You’re asking me to make a weapon.”

Rook smiled, thin and cold. “No. I’m asking you to make a future.”

Kael closed the door. The lab fell silent again, save for the hum of the PCR machine and the pulse of the glowing tiles.

He opened the vial. The liquid shimmered. He loaded it into the machine.

“Cycle one,” he whispered. “Denature at 95°C. Hold for 30 seconds.”

The machine whirred. The screen blinked.

*Amplifying…*

He pulled up the primer sequence—neural enhancer, pre-collapse, untested. He’d seen it before. In a dead scientist’s journal. *“Stabilizes genetic memory. But may induce… perception shifts.”*

He hesitated.

Then, he pressed *Enter*.

The machine roared to life. The glow from the tiles deepened. The walls seemed to pulse. And in the silence, Kael heard it—the faint, rhythmic thrum of something *alive* beneath the floor, beneath the city, beneath the bones of the world.

The PCR finished.

The screen flashed:

**Amplification Complete.**
**New Sequence: Oryza sativa-Neurotrophin-7 Hybrid.**
**Stability: 78% (Projected).**
**Side Effects: Unconfirmed.**

Kael looked at the vial. The liquid glowed brighter.

He picked up the scalpel.

And smiled.

Because for the first time in years, he wasn’t afraid of what he might become.

He was afraid of what the world *would* become—without him.

“Stabilization protocol,” Rook said, handing over the vial. “I’ve got the primer sequence. It’s… experimental. From a pre-collapse neural enhancer. Designed to slow degradation. But it’s not tested. Not on plants. And not on humans.”

Kael stared at the vial. The liquid inside glowed faintly—same blue as the floor. *Photobacterium* again.

“You want me to splice it into the wheat DNA. And test it on people?”

Rook didn’t flinch. “The settlement’s running on nutrient paste and recycled algae. Children are dying. You’ve got the tools. You’ve got the courage. You’ve got the *tremor*.”

Kael looked down at his hand. The tremor had lessened since the neurotrophin edits. But the side effects? He saw things now. Not just the neurons—*memories*. Fragments of people he’d never met, faces in the static of old data streams. Was it the gene edit? Or was it the world finally catching up?

“You’re not asking for a crop,” Kael said. “You’re asking me to make a weapon.”

Rook smiled, thin and cold. “No. I’m asking you to make a future.”

Kael closed the door. The lab fell silent again, save for the hum of the PCR machine and the pulse of the glowing tiles.

He opened the vial. The liquid shimmered. He loaded it into the machine.

“Cycle one,” he whispered. “Denature at 95°C. Hold for 30 seconds.”

The machine whirred. The screen blinked.

*Amplifying…*

He pulled up the primer sequence—neural enhancer, pre-collapse, untested. He’d seen it before. In a dead scientist’s journal. *“Stabilizes genetic memory. But may induce… perception shifts.”*

He hesitated.

Then, he pressed *Enter*.

The machine roared to life. The glow from the tiles deepened. The walls seemed to pulse. And in the silence, Kael heard it—the faint, rhythmic thrum of something *alive* beneath the floor, beneath the city, beneath the bones of the world.

The PCR finished.

The screen flashed:

**Amplification Complete.**
**New Sequence: Oryza sativa-Neurotrophin-7 Hybrid.**
**Stability: 78% (Projected).**
**Side Effects: Unconfirmed.**

Kael looked at the vial. The liquid glowed brighter.

He picked up the scalpel.

And smiled.

Because for the first time in years, he wasn’t afraid of what he might become.

He was afraid of what the world *would* become—without him.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The piece nails the prompt’s core requirements: a post-collapse biopunk lab, jury-rigged PCR rig, black-market contract, and a biohacker dosing himself with untested edits. World-building details—hand-cranked generator, UV-glowing tiles, “dying star” display—are vivid and specific. The prose is lean, tactile, and mostly consistent in its grimy, rain-soaked tone. Kael’s tremor and the hallucinated “neuron stars” give a credible physical cost to DIY gene-hacking, and the decision to splice neural code into rice is a pleasingly reckless escalation.

Yet the story stays small: one room, one visitor, one choice. That’s efficient, but it also means the contract itself is undercooked. Rook arrives, delivers a vial and a line of exposition, then exits. We never see the settlement’s starving kids, the stakes are only asserted, not felt, so Kael’s final “smile” lands as a leap rather than a culmination. Dialogue is functional but thin; Rook’s voice is indistinguishable from Kael’s internal monologue, and both speak in the same compressed, noir-ish clauses. Emotional complexity is hinted at (memory leakage, beauty in pain) yet never explored—Kael never doubts aloud, never weighs the lives he might save against the horrors he might unleash. The ending beat—“afraid of what the world would become—without him”—sounds cool but isn’t earned by any prior moral wrestling.

Stylistically the piece is confident: sentences drive forward, metaphors stay in the biopunk register, and there’s no purple excess. Still, the imagery repeats (everything glows blue; everything pulses) and the emotional register is static: grim determination from line one to line last. A single moment of sensory levity or remembered pre-lapsarian warmth could have sharpened the darkness, but the story keeps its fist clenched, mistaking monotony for intensity.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment.

First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The air on the hill was sharp enough to cut, even through my woolen coat. Below, the village slept—its lights dimmed like dying embers. Above, the sky was a vast, bruised velvet, stitched with stars so bright they hurt. I stood on the edge of the mound, my breath puffing white, my fingers numb inside my gloves. Astrid stood beside me, bareheaded, her dark braid coiled like a serpent down her back. She’d insisted I leave my hood down. “The spirits need to see your face,” she’d said, as if that were a simple, natural thing.

We’d come here after dark, following a path only she seemed to know. The earth was damp beneath my boots, the grass brittle. The mound—old, uneven, covered in lichen and moss—wasn’t marked on any map I’d seen. No sign, no fence. Just the silence and the weight of something ancient beneath our feet. Astrid called it Útiseta. *Sitting out.* She’d said it meant “to wait with the dead.”

“You don’t have to believe,” she whispered, her voice low and steady, like she was reading from a script she’d memorized. “But you have to *do*.” She handed me a small bundle wrapped in oilcloth—cracked leather, smelling faintly of damp earth and iron. Inside: a single white feather, a scrap of red thread, and a piece of birch bark etched with symbols I didn’t recognize. “You hold it when the bell rings. Don’t let go.”

I didn’t ask what the bell was for. I didn’t ask why she knew this place, or how her grandmother had taught her these things. I just wanted to believe it was all a game—something we’d made up to scare ourselves, to feel brave in the dark. But Astrid wasn’t scared. She was *focused*. Her eyes were wide, her face pale in the starlight, but her hands didn’t tremble.

We sat. Not on the mound, but on the edge, knees drawn up, backs straight. The cold seeped through my jeans. The silence pressed in, thick and expectant. I kept glancing at the village below. No movement. No sound. Just the faint hum of the refrigerator in my new bedroom, a memory of home.

Then, the church bell.

One chime. Clear, metallic, echoing across the valley. Not a warning. Not a call to prayer. Just *one*. It rang at exactly midnight.

My breath caught. I clutched the bundle tighter.

Astrid didn’t flinch. She closed her eyes. “Now,” she murmured. “Now it begins.”

I didn’t know what I was supposed to do. I just sat there, heart hammering, waiting for something—anything—to happen. The wind stirred the grass. A distant owl cried. That was it.

Then, the ground beneath me shifted.

Not much—just a faint tremor, like the earth sighing. I jerked my head up. The mound seemed… darker. The shadows between the stones deepened. I blinked, but the darkness didn’t recede.

Astrid opened her eyes. “You feel it?”

I swallowed. “What?”

“The breath,” she said. “It’s coming from below.”

I looked at her. Her face was still, but her pupils were wide, almost black. I wanted to laugh. I wanted to stand up and run. But I didn’t. I stayed. Because if I left now, I’d be admitting I was afraid. And Astrid would never let me live it down.

Then, the wind changed.

It didn’t howl. It *whispered*. Not in words, not really—but a susurration, like voices just out of earshot. I strained to hear, but the syllables dissolved before they reached me. I looked at Astrid. Her lips were moving. She wasn’t speaking aloud. She was *singing*. A low, guttural hum, something older than Swedish, older than the church that had never been built on this hill.

My skin prickled. The air grew colder. My breath came in short, shallow gasps. I gripped the bundle tighter. The feather felt warm now, almost alive.

“Listen,” Astrid said, her voice suddenly sharp. “Not with your ears. With your bones.”

I closed my eyes. I tried. I focused on the cold in my fingers, the ache in my back, the thud of my pulse in my throat. And then—just for a second—I *felt* it. A presence. Not in the air. Not in the wind. But *under* me. Beneath the mound. Something vast, still, and awake.

I opened my eyes. The stars seemed closer. The silence deeper. And then, from the center of the mound, a low, rhythmic *thump*. Like a heartbeat.

I gasped. Astrid smiled. Not a happy smile. A knowing one.

“It’s listening,” she said.

I wanted to scream. I wanted to run. But my legs wouldn’t move. My hands were locked around the bundle. The feather pulsed in my palm.

Then—another sound. A voice. Not Astrid’s. Not the wind. A whisper, soft and close, like it came from inside my own skull.

*You are seen.*

I jerked back. The mound was still. The wind had died. The silence returned, heavier than before.

Astrid stood. “We’re done,” she said, her voice normal again, almost casual. “It’s over.”

I couldn’t speak. My throat was tight. My body was shaking.

We walked back down the hill in silence. The village lights were still dark. The church bell hadn’t rung again.

When we reached the edge of the woods, Astrid stopped. “You didn’t believe,” she said, turning to me. “But you *felt* it. That’s the point.”

I didn’t answer. I just stared at her, wondering if she’d been lying all along. Or if I’d just lost my mind.

Now, years later, I still wake up in the middle of the night, cold, and I swear I hear it—the faint, distant chime. One note. At midnight.

I never told anyone what happened that night. Not my parents. Not my friends. Not even Astrid, when we met again in Stockholm last year. She looked at me and smiled, like she remembered everything. Like she *knew*.

And sometimes, when the wind is just right, I think I feel something beneath my feet. Not the ground. Something older.

Something waiting.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a solid, atmospheric vignette that hits most of the prompt’s beats: rural 1990s Sweden, two teenage girls, a single midnight ritual on a burial mound, first-person retrospective, and deliberate ambiguity about the supernatural. The prose is lean, sensory, and confident; images like “the sky was a vast, bruised velvet” or “her dark braid coiled like a serpent” are vivid without slipping into purple. The pacing is tight: we arrive at the mound quickly, the ritual escalates in discrete, credible steps, and we exit before the spell breaks. The retrospective frame is present but unobtrusive, exactly as requested.

Character-wise, Astrid is sketched with economical menace—calm, focused, slightly predatory in her certainty—while Linnea’s Stockholm-bred skepticism and need for social acceptance feel authentic. Their dynamic is less friendship than slow-motion recruitment, which is creepier and more believable than equal footing. The mounting ambiguity is well handled: every “supernatural” beat (the tremor, the heartbeat, the whisper) can still be read as suggestion and adrenaline. The final paragraph lands the story in a place of lasting unease rather than cheap jump-scare, earning its darkness.

Weak spots are small but real. Dialogue is sparse and functional; Astrid’s repeated “Now it begins”/“It’s listening” edges on cliché, and Linnea’s interiority sometimes tells us the emotion we already see (“I wanted to scream. I wanted to run.”). The symbolic bundle (feather, thread, bark) is introduced with fanfare but never integrates into the experience—it’s a prop that doesn’t repay attention. The church-bell device feels contrived: a single stroke at exact midnight in a tiny village is convenient, and the story never admits that clocks might differ. Finally, while the retrospective coda supplies a chill, it also compresses twenty-five years into two sentences, giving us no sense of how the night actually shaped Linnea’s life—an unearned leap from teen trauma to adult fixation.

Still, the piece succeeds at sustained dread and leaves the reader balancing on the same mound of doubt as the narrator. It is technically accomplished, emotionally coherent, and respects the prompt’s constraints without feeling boxed in by them.

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment.

individual_results.model_response:
The air tasted like wet stone and old iron. I remember that first, sharp breath as we stepped off the path, boots sinking into moss so thick it swallowed sound. It was midnight, the kind of midnight that feels like it’s holding its breath. The village of Västernorrland had shrunk behind us, swallowed by the forest, and now there was only the mound—*Útiseta*, Astrid had called it, her voice low and certain. “The Place of the Watched Ones.”

We’d been preparing for hours. Not with incantations or candles, not like in the movies, but with things that felt more real: Astrid’s grandmother’s silver ring, cold as a dead fish, pressed into my palm. A scrap of linen from an old shawl, stained with something brown I didn’t ask about. And the silence—she’d insisted we say nothing after the first step. No whispers, no laughter. “The dead don’t like noise,” she said, as if that were the most obvious thing in the world.

Now, we sat on the mound’s edge, backs to the earth, knees drawn up, hands resting on our thighs. The mist curled around us like smoke, thick and pearlescent under the moon. It didn’t move. It just *was*, clinging to the stones, seeping into my clothes, into my bones.

Astrid didn’t speak. She just stared straight ahead, her face pale in the silver light. I kept glancing at her—her dark hair pulled back, her jaw tight. She looked different now. Not like the girl who’d laughed with me at school, who wore her hair in braids and carried a sketchbook full of drawings of reindeer and runes. This was someone else. Someone older.

I should’ve left. I knew that. My fingers trembled. I’d told myself this was just a game—Astrid’s idea of rebellion, of proving she wasn’t just another boring village girl. But the way she’d described the mound, the way she’d traced the old symbols in the dirt with her finger earlier, the way she’d whispered, *“They remember when you’re still.”* It wasn’t just stories. It felt like a warning.

Then, the wind stopped.

Not a breeze. Not a rustle. The entire forest went quiet. Even the crickets—those tiny, relentless things that had buzzed all evening—fell silent. I felt it in my teeth. A pressure in the air. Like the world had paused to listen.

Astrid turned her head slowly. Her eyes met mine. Not with amusement. Not with teasing. With something like dread. Or maybe it was expectation.

Then, the mist shifted.

Not a wave. Not a swirl. It *pulled*, as if drawn by something beneath the surface. The glow deepened—pale green, almost sickly. And in that light, I saw them.

Not people. Not shapes. Just *presence*. A hush in the mist, a weight where nothing should be. I couldn’t blink. My throat locked.

Astrid reached into her coat and pulled out a small pouch. She opened it. Inside—dried roots, a feather, something that looked like a child’s tooth. She scattered it into the air. It didn’t fall. It *hovered*, suspended in the stillness.

Then, a sound.

Not a voice. Not a word. But a *hum*, low and guttural, vibrating up through the ground into my legs. My knees shook. I wanted to scream. I wanted to run. But I couldn’t move. My body was full of lead.

Astrid leaned forward. Her voice, when it came, was barely a breath, but it cut through the hum like a knife.

“They’re here,” she said. “They’re listening.”

I swallowed. My tongue felt thick. “What… what do they want?”

She didn’t answer. Just stared at the mist. Then, slowly, she raised her hand—palm open, like she was offering something.

And in that moment, the air *changed*. The mist thinned, just for a second. And in that thinning, I saw it.

A face.

Not human. Not animal. A shape with too many eyes, set deep in shadow. It didn’t move. It just *was*, suspended in the fog, staring back at me with something like recognition.

I screamed.

The sound tore from my throat, raw and jagged. The moment I did, the face vanished. The mist thickened again. The hum faded. The wind returned—cold, sharp, biting.

Astrid turned to me. Her face was pale, but her eyes were alight. “You saw it,” she said. “You *saw*.”

I couldn’t speak. I just nodded, tears burning my cheeks.

She stood, brushing moss from her jeans. “It’s not dangerous,” she said, as if we’d just finished a game. “They just want to be remembered.”

But I wasn’t sure she believed that. I wasn’t sure *I* believed it.

We walked back in silence. The path seemed longer. The forest darker. I kept glancing over my shoulder, half-expecting to see that face again, or worse—something behind me.

When we reached the edge of the village, Astrid stopped.

“Don’t tell anyone,” she said. “Not even your parents. They wouldn’t understand.”

I nodded, still shaking.

She gave me a small, sad smile. “You’re one of us now.”

I didn’t know what that meant.

Now, years later, I live in Stockholm. I’ve never told anyone about Útiseta. Not my mother, not my therapist. But sometimes, when the wind is still and the air is thick, I feel it—the pressure in the silence. The weight of being watched.

And I still wake up with the taste of wet stone on my tongue.

And in that moment, the air *changed*. The mist thinned, just for a second. And in that thinning, I saw it.

A face.

Not human. Not animal. A shape with too many eyes, set deep in shadow. It didn’t move. It just *was*, suspended in the fog, staring back at me with something like recognition.

I screamed.

The sound tore from my throat, raw and jagged. The moment I did, the face vanished. The mist thickened again. The hum faded. The wind returned—cold, sharp, biting.

Astrid turned to me. Her face was pale, but her eyes were alight. “You saw it,” she said. “You *saw*.”

I couldn’t speak. I just nodded, tears burning my cheeks.

She stood, brushing moss from her jeans. “It’s not dangerous,” she said, as if we’d just finished a game. “They just want to be remembered.”

But I wasn’t sure she believed that. I wasn’t sure *I* believed it.

We walked back in silence. The path seemed longer. The forest darker. I kept glancing over my shoulder, half-expecting to see that face again, or worse—something behind me.

When we reached the edge of the village, Astrid stopped.

“Don’t tell anyone,” she said. “Not even your parents. They wouldn’t understand.”

I nodded, still shaking.

She gave me a small, sad smile. “You’re one of us now.”

I didn’t know what that meant.

Now, years later, I live in Stockholm. I’ve never told anyone about Útiseta. Not my mother, not my therapist. But sometimes, when the wind is still and the air is thick, I feel it—the pressure in the silence. The weight of being watched.

And I still wake up with the taste of wet stone on my tongue.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the prompt’s structural demands: first-person, past-tense, rural northern Sweden, mid-1990s, single midnight excursion to a burial mound, ambiguity about the supernatural, and a transparent adult recollection frame. Word count is inside the 1000-word ballpark. Yet the execution is thin. Linnea’s voice is competent but generic; Astrid never becomes more than a spooky tour-guide. The “preparations” amount to three props and a silence rule—no textured detail of how these girls actually talk themselves into staying, no convincing mix of adolescent bravado and half-believed folklore. The mound itself is described in repetitive mist-and-moss language; we never feel the place’s age or its local reputation. The central apparition is a cliché cluster—“shape with too many eyes,” green glow, hum rising through the ground—delivered in short declarative bursts that tell us Linnea is scared but don’t let the fear accrue naturally. Dialogue is functional but sparse and on-the-nose (“They’re here. They’re listening.”). The ending tag (“You’re one of us now”) is horror-movie merchandise rather than earned transformation. Throughout, the prose is clean, but clean in the way of a school assignment: no surprising metaphors, no sensory layering, no rhythm that mimics the rising dread. Ambiguity is asserted rather than cultivated; once the face appears, the balance tilts decisively toward the supernatural, so the requested “maybe it’s only psychology” wobble collapses. Finally, the adult frame adds nothing except a last-paragraph reminder that the memory lingers—an obligatory coda that feels tacked on.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment.

First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The wind didn’t howl. It *whispered*. That’s what I remember most. Not the cold – though it bit through my thin jacket like needles – but the way the pine trees sighed through their branches, a susurration that felt too deliberate, too close to words. It was the kind of night that made your skin crawl even when you weren’t sure why.

Midnight. Or close enough. Astrid’s breath plumed white in the air as she crouched beside me on the uneven, moss-slicked stones of the burial mound. *Útiseta*. The name alone had sent a jolt through me when she’d whispered it earlier, back in her dark, peat-smelling kitchen, her grandmother’s old ledger open on the table. “Sitting out,” she’d said, her eyes bright with a fervor that felt both childish and ancient. “To receive knowledge. From the ones who sleep beneath.”

I’d agreed. Stupidly. Reluctantly. Because Astrid was the only person who didn’t make me feel like a lost, city-slicker ghost in this frozen village. Because she knew things – about the forest, about the old stones, about the way the light changed just before dawn. Because she’d shown me how to weave a simple charm from birch bark and ash that made Maja, the girl who’d laughed at my accent, trip over her own feet the next day. “Just a little nudge,” Astrid had grinned, utterly unrepentant. “Like a whisper in the wind.”

Now, the wind was *here*. And it felt less like a natural sound and more like a presence. Astrid had insisted on the ritual’s purity. No phones. No torches. Just the faint, grey glow of the moon filtering through the high pines. We’d brought only two things: a small, smooth river stone, black as obsidian, and a single, dried sprig of mugwort. “For clarity,” she’d said, pressing the cold stone into my palm. “For the path.”

We sat on the largest, flattest stone at the mound’s heart, backs straight, hands resting on our knees. Astrid’s instructions were calm, almost bored, yet laced with a precision that chilled me. “You don’t speak. Not a word. Not even to yourself. You listen. The wind carries things. The stones remember. You let them speak through you.” She’d mimicked the pine’s sighs with her lips, a low, rhythmic sound that sent shivers down my spine. “Focus on the stone. Feel its weight. Feel the cold. That’s the world beneath.”

I focused. I focused on the stone’s chill, the rough texture against my skin, the way my fingers ached. I focused on the wind. It wasn’t just rustling. It was *shifting*. A pause. Then a sigh that seemed to come from directly behind me, though there was only empty darkness and the slope of the mound. I flinched, my breath catching. Astrid didn’t move. Her eyes were closed, her face serene in the moonlight.

*Just the wind. Just the wind.*

Then, a sound. Not from the trees. From *under* the stone beneath me. A faint, wet *thump*. Like something heavy settling. My heart hammered against my ribs. I squeezed the stone so hard my knuckles turned white. I didn’t move. I couldn’t. Astrid’s voice, when it came, was a mere breath against my ear, yet it cut through the silence like a knife.

“*They’re listening,*” she murmured. “*They know you’re here.*”

I tried to breathe. I couldn’t. The air felt thick, cold, *wrong*. The whispers intensified. Not just the pines now. A susurration from the earth itself, a chorus of faint, indistinct voices layered beneath the wind. My skin prickled. I felt watched. Not just by Astrid, but by the dark, the stones, the frozen earth. I saw shapes in the shadows between the pines – not trees, but figures, tall and thin, standing motionless, their heads tilted towards us. I blinked. They were gone. Just the trees, swaying.

Astrid shifted slightly. She didn’t open her eyes. “They show you what you need to see. What you’re afraid to know.” Her voice was flat, devoid of fear, almost… pleased. “You want to know what Maja said about you behind your back? What Lars thinks about your mother? The stone will show you. The wind will carry it.”

*No.* The thought screamed inside my head. *This isn’t real. It’s just Astrid. It’s the dark. It’s the cold.* But the stone in my hand felt heavier than stone should. The whispers seemed to coil around my thoughts, twisting them. I thought of Maja’s laughter. I thought of Lars’s sidelong glance. The wind sighed, and for a fraction of a second, I *heard* Maja’s voice, sharp and mocking, cutting through the silence: *“...freak. Just like her mother…”* Then it was gone, replaced by a deeper, wetter sound, like mud shifting.

I gasped. A real, ragged sound. I clutched the stone tighter, pressing it into my palm. Astrid’s eyes snapped open. They weren’t her usual green. They were darker, deeper, reflecting the moonlight like polished obsidian. Her face was utterly still, expressionless.

“*Silence,*” she whispered, the command sharp and final. “*The veil is thin. You break it, you break everything.*”

The wind died. Utter, suffocating silence descended. The world held its breath. The stars seemed to dim. The only sound was the frantic thudding of my own heart, echoing in my skull. The cold wasn’t just on my skin anymore; it was inside me, deep in my bones. I felt the weight of the mound beneath me, not just stone, but *pressure*. The pressure of countless unseen eyes. The pressure of things that should not be known.

I didn’t know how long we sat there, frozen in that terrifying silence. Minutes? An hour? Time dissolved. The only certainty was the stone, the cold, and the crushing weight of being utterly, irrevocably *seen*.

Then, Astrid exhaled. A long, slow breath that fogged the air. Her eyes cleared, the obsidian depth receding, leaving only the familiar, slightly bored green. She stretched, a mundane, human gesture that felt jarring, almost obscene.

“Done,” she said, her voice back to its normal, casual tone. “You felt it, didn’t you? The knowing.”

I couldn’t speak. My mouth was dry, my throat tight. I nodded, a tiny, jerky movement.

She grinned, a flash of white teeth in the moonlight. “Told you it worked. Now, let’s go. Before the real cold sets in.” She stood, offering me a hand.

I took it, my fingers numb and trembling. As I scrambled to my feet, the black stone fell from my hand onto the moss. I didn’t pick it up. I couldn’t. The silence, the weight, the whispers… they didn’t stop. They just… retreated. Like a tide pulling back, leaving behind a shore of cold dread.

We walked back towards the village, the pines closing in behind us, their shadows deep and watchful. The wind sighed again, a soft, familiar sound. But I knew. I *knew* it wasn’t just the wind. And I knew, with a cold certainty that settled into my bones, that I’d crossed a line. Not just with Astrid. With something older. Something that had been waiting. And I wasn’t sure I’d ever be able to walk back across it.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece nails the prompt’s essentials: rural 1990s Norrland, two teenage girls, a single midnight ritual on a burial mound, first-person retrospective, and a scrupulously maintained ambiguity about whether anything actually answers. The voice is consistent, the pacing tight, and the sensory detail (cold stone, pine-sighs, the wet “thump” under the rock) keeps the reader inside Linnea’s skin. Astrid’s mix of bored instruction and cultic certainty feels adolescent and creepy at once, so the power dynamic is believable. The prose is controlled: no Gothic adjective overload, no cliché jump-scares; the horror accrues through restraint. The ending lands exactly where it should—Linnea irrevocably altered, yet nothing proven supernatural—so the darkness feels earned rather than imposed. Minor weaknesses: a few adjectives (“obsidian,” “suffocating”) flirt with purple, and the retrospective frame is so understated that its present-day echo is almost invisible, but these are quibbles. Overall it’s a poised, unsettling miniature that trusts the reader to do half the work, which is what good folk horror demands.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The saxophone wails like a wounded thing, low and raw, cutting through the humid air like a blade. I’ve been walking for hours—maybe four? Five? Time’s got no shape here. Just heat, noise, and this weird, electric hum under my skin that says *run, run, run* even though my legs are screaming.

*Okay. Okay. You’re not dead. You’re not in Tennessee. You’re not… him. You’re Taylor. You’re… you.*

I stop under a striped awning, pressing my back against the cool brick. My backpack—stolen from the closet, packed in panic—is heavy. A change of clothes, a half-eaten granola bar, a water bottle, my phone (dead), and a crumpled note from Mom that I can’t bring myself to throw away.

*“Taylor, we need to talk. This isn’t a phase.”*

Like it’s *not* a phase. Like it’s not me, breathing, living, *being*.

I blink hard. The street’s a blur—tourists in bright shirts, locals in faded jeans, a man selling beignets on a cart, the scent of fried dough and something sweet and rotting in the air. New Orleans. Not the kind of place where people look at you and *know* you’re broken. Or maybe they do. Maybe everyone here is broken. That’s the vibe.

A hand taps my shoulder.

I jump like I’ve been shot.

“Whoa, easy,” says a voice—low, smooth, like smoke over gravel. “Didn’t mean to scare you.”

I turn. Girl, maybe my age, maybe older. Black, braids pulled into a messy knot, eyes sharp and dark like polished obsidian. She’s got a leather jacket with a patch that says “SOS” in faded red. Her left hand is wrapped in a bandage, peeking out from under her sleeve. She’s holding a cigarette, but not lighting it. Just letting it burn.

“You look like you’re about to vanish,” she says, exhaling a slow stream of smoke. “Like, literally. You’re breathing in, but your chest isn’t moving.”

I swallow. “I’m… I’m not vanishing. I’m just… walking.”

“Right. Walking. That’s what you do when you’ve got nowhere to go.” She takes a drag. “I’m Jules.”

“Taylor.”

“Taylor. Like the river?”

“No. Like… Taylor Swift. Or Taylor Lautner. Doesn’t matter.”

She chuckles. “Mm. Either way, you’re not from here. You don’t walk like someone who lives here. You walk like you’re trying not to be seen.”

I flinch. “I don’t want to be seen.”

“Good. Then we’re already on the same page.” She nods toward the sax player still blowing his soul out on the corner. “He’s my uncle. Plays every day. Says the music keeps the bad ghosts away.”

“Bad ghosts?”

“Yeah.” She looks at me, really looks. “You got one?”

I want to say no. I want to say *I’m fine, I’m just tired, I’m just trying to find a place to sleep*. But the words don’t come. Instead, I whisper, “My mom called me a ‘concerning behavioral pattern.’ Like I’m a science experiment.”

Jules doesn’t laugh. Doesn’t flinch. Just nods slowly. “Yeah. I know that one.”

I stare. “You… know?”

“Used to live in Nashville. Same deal. Mom said I was ‘dramatic.’ Dad said I was ‘a problem.’” She taps her temple. “Turns out, I’m just… me. And that’s the problem.”

I breathe out. A shaky, ugly sound. “I came out two days ago. Told them I’m trans. They didn’t… they didn’t say anything. Just looked at me like I’d grown a second head.”

“Yeah,” Jules says. “They don’t know how to handle it. So they pretend it’s not real.”

“I’m real,” I whisper. “I’m *real*.”

“I know,” she says, and for a second, her voice cracks. Just a little. “I know.”

We stand there in silence, the saxophone still screaming its sorrow into the sky.

“So,” she says, “you got a plan?”

“Not really. Just… keep moving. Find a shelter. A bus station. Somewhere I can sleep without getting robbed.”

“Shelter’s a gamble. Some are full. Some are worse than the streets.” She takes a long drag. “But there’s a place. Back alleys near the Quarter. Old church. Roof’s busted, but dry. They call it ‘The Vault.’ You can sleep there. If you’re quiet.”

“Why help me?”

She looks at me, and for the first time, I see something raw—something like fear, but not fear. Like *recognition*.

“Because I was you,” she says. “And I didn’t know anyone who’d help me. I almost died in a parking garage once. Just… sat there. Didn’t know how to call for help. Didn’t think anyone would answer.”

I swallow. “You’re not… you’re not gonna hurt me, are you?”

She laughs—short, bitter. “I’m the one who’s been hurt, Taylor. Not the one doing it.” She tosses the cigarette into a gutter. “Come on. I’ll show you the way. But you gotta promise me one thing.”

“What?”

“Don’t tell anyone you met me. Not even the people at the Vault. If they know I brought you, they’ll ask questions. And I don’t do questions.”

I nod. “I won’t.”

She gives me a slow, careful smile. “Good. Then let’s go. And Taylor?”

“Yeah?”

“Your name’s not a phase. It’s not a game. You’re not broken. You’re just… surviving.”

We walk down the street, the saxophone still playing behind us—like a ghost, like a prayer, like the sound of someone finally being heard.

I want to say no. I want to say *I’m fine, I’m just tired, I’m just trying to find a place to sleep*. But the words don’t come. Instead, I whisper, “My mom called me a ‘concerning behavioral pattern.’ Like I’m a science experiment.”

Jules doesn’t laugh. Doesn’t flinch. Just nods slowly. “Yeah. I know that one.”

I stare. “You… know?”

“Used to live in Nashville. Same deal. Mom said I was ‘dramatic.’ Dad said I was ‘a problem.’” She taps her temple. “Turns out, I’m just… me. And that’s the problem.”

I breathe out. A shaky, ugly sound. “I came out two days ago. Told them I’m trans. They didn’t… they didn’t say anything. Just looked at me like I’d grown a second head.”

“Yeah,” Jules says. “They don’t know how to handle it. So they pretend it’s not real.”

“I’m real,” I whisper. “I’m *real*.”

“I know,” she says, and for a second, her voice cracks. Just a little. “I know.”

We stand there in silence, the saxophone still screaming its sorrow into the sky.

“So,” she says, “you got a plan?”

“Not really. Just… keep moving. Find a shelter. A bus station. Somewhere I can sleep without getting robbed.”

“Shelter’s a gamble. Some are full. Some are worse than the streets.” She takes a long drag. “But there’s a place. Back alleys near the Quarter. Old church. Roof’s busted, but dry. They call it ‘The Vault.’ You can sleep there. If you’re quiet.”

“Why help me?”

She looks at me, and for the first time, I see something raw—something like fear, but not fear. Like *recognition*.

“Because I was you,” she says. “And I didn’t know anyone who’d help me. I almost died in a parking garage once. Just… sat there. Didn’t know how to call for help. Didn’t think anyone would answer.”

I swallow. “You’re not… you’re not gonna hurt me, are you?”

She laughs—short, bitter. “I’m the one who’s been hurt, Taylor. Not the one doing it.” She tosses the cigarette into a gutter. “Come on. I’ll show you the way. But you gotta promise me one thing.”

“What?”

“Don’t tell anyone you met me. Not even the people at the Vault. If they know I brought you, they’ll ask questions. And I don’t do questions.”

I nod. “I won’t.”

She gives me a slow, careful smile. “Good. Then let’s go. And Taylor?”

“Yeah?”

“Your name’s not a phase. It’s not a game. You’re not broken. You’re just… surviving.”

We walk down the street, the saxophone still playing behind us—like a ghost, like a prayer, like the sound of someone finally being heard.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a solid YA vignette that obeys almost every constraint in the prompt: first-person, mixed-tense, internal monologue, New-Orleans first day, meeting another runaway, danger signals, trans-coming-out baggage. Taylor’s voice is convincingly adolescent—self-lacerating, ironic, exhausted—without slipping into caricature. The city is sketched quickly but with enough sensory detail (saxophone, beignet steam, humid air) to feel present. Jules enters as a credible mirror-character: older, warier, black, queer-coded, carrying her own damage. Their dialogue is functional, never sparkling, but it avoids the “after-school-special” tone that sinks most issue-driven YA. The emotional stakes stay intimate: Taylor needs to hear “you’re real,” and Jules needs to stay invisible; the moment of mutual recognition is small, not melodramatic.

Still, the chapter never quite transcends its function as setup. The saxophone “wounded thing” line is strong, but the next fifty adjectives (“low and raw… like a blade… electric hum”) start to pile up without deepening. Internal monologue circles the same two thoughts—Mom’s rejection / I’m real—so the emotional curve is flat. Jules’s backstory is delivered in two tidy speeches that feel more like serviceable exposition than lived history. Nothing actually threatens Taylor in-scene: no cop, no creep, no empty stomach, no rainstorm. The promised “dangers” are only alluded to, so the tension never rises above ambient melancholy. The ending beat—“you’re just surviving”—is earned, but it lands exactly where the opening paragraph told us we were going, so the journey feels short.

Technically the prose is clean, but the rhythm is monotonous: most sentences are the same length, stacked with em-dashes and italicized self-talk, which starts to read like a single sustained key on the sax rather than a melody. There’s no genuine surprise or specificity—no detail about New Orleans that couldn’t be swapped for any other Southern city with a street musician. The chapter does what it needs to do, but it doesn’t leave a scar or a laugh, and YA that doesn’t leave either is forgettable.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter 3: Gone South**

I’m not supposed to be here.

That thought loops like a broken record in my skull as I stand on the sidewalk outside a shuttered café on Frenchmen Street, the air thick with the smell of fried food, damp concrete, and something sweet—like jasmine or maybe rotting peaches. My hands are shaking. Not from the heat. From *everything*. The city is alive in a way my town never was—music spills from open windows, people talk too fast, laugh too loud, move like they’ve got somewhere important to go. I don’t. I’m just… here. Alive. But not *me*. Not the real me. Not the one who used to believe they’d be okay if they just stayed quiet.

My phone buzzes. 12%. I don’t even look. I don’t want to see Mom’s name. Or Dad’s. Or the school counselor’s smug little “Let’s talk” message. I don’t want to hear the guilt. I don’t want to hear *anything*.

I take a breath. It doesn’t help.

Two days ago, I told them I was trans. Not “maybe,” not “I think,” not “I’m exploring.” I said it like it was a fact. Like I was finally breathing. And the room went cold. Mom started crying. Dad just stared at the floor like I’d just spat on his shoes. My little brother ran out. That was the end of it. The silence afterward was worse than the shouting.

So I packed a backpack. Just clothes, a photo of my mom when she was younger (before the world got heavy), my journal, and a half-empty bottle of water. I didn’t even say goodbye. I just… left. The car ride was quiet, the driver a guy named Rico who said he was “going to the Bayou for a job.” He didn’t ask questions. I didn’t offer answers. When we hit the edge of New Orleans, he dropped me off like I was a package. “You good, kid?” he asked, eyes flicking to my face like I was a problem he didn’t want to solve.

“I’m fine,” I lied.

Now I’m here. Alone. With 12% battery and no idea where to go.

I wander, half-dazed, past a mural of a woman in a red dress holding a trumpet, her face painted in gold. A street performer plays a saxophone so raw it makes my chest ache. I want to cry. I want to scream. I want to disappear.

Then I see her.

A girl, maybe my age, sitting on the curb with her back against a brick wall. She’s got one leg tucked under her, the other stretched out, a beat-up guitar case open beside her. Her hair is dyed electric blue, shaved on one side, long and black on the other. She’s wearing a leather jacket covered in patches—some with words, some with symbols I don’t recognize. Her eyes are sharp, tired, and *watching* me.

I try to keep walking. But she speaks first.

“You look like you’re about to fall apart,” she says, voice low, like she’s used to being heard over noise.

I freeze.

“I’m not—” I start.

“You’re not *fine*,” she cuts in. “I can see it. Like, *really* see it. You’re running. Or hiding. Or both.”

My stomach drops. I don’t know how to answer. I don’t want to talk. But I also don’t want to be alone.

“I’m… not running,” I say, even though I know it’s a lie. “I’m just… exploring.”

She snorts. “Exploring? In a town where the only thing more dangerous than the humidity is the people who think they’re smarter than you?”

I blink. “You live here?”

“Born and raised,” she says, plucking a string on her guitar. “Name’s Jules. You?”

“Taylor.”

“Taylor. Like the river?”

I flinch. “No. Like… Taylor Swift?”

She laughs. “Oh, *that* Taylor. Cool. So you’re a runaway, then?”

I don’t answer. But I don’t deny it either.

Jules tilts her head. “You don’t have to say anything. But if you’re gonna be out here, you need to know how it works. No one’s gonna hand you a free meal just ‘cause you look sad. You gotta earn it. Or steal it. Or charm it. Or all three.”

I swallow. “I don’t know how to do any of that.”

“Neither did I,” she says, quiet now. “First time I hit the streets, I was 15. My mom was gone. My dad? He wasn’t around. I thought I could just… disappear. Like I wasn’t real. But the city doesn’t let you disappear. It *eats* you. Or it *changes* you.”

She looks at me, really looks. “You’re not like the others. You don’t look like you’ve been here before. You look like you just got here.”

“I did.”

“Two days?”

I stare. “How—?”

She grins, sharp and knowing. “You walk like someone who just left something behind. Like you’re still carrying it.”

I feel my eyes burn.

“Look,” she says, softer now. “I don’t care who you are or why you’re here. But if you’re gonna survive this city, you need a plan. And a place to crash. I’ve got a cot in an old warehouse near the river. Not safe. Not pretty. But dry.”

I want to say no. I want to run. But I don’t know where else to go. And the truth? I’m so tired. So *done*.

“Why help me?” I ask.

She shrugs. “Because I remember what it’s like to be scared. And because you’re not like the others who come through here. You’re… different. Like you’re not trying to pretend. You’re just… *there*.”

I don’t know if that’s a compliment or not. But I nod.

“Okay,” I whisper. “I’ll come.”

Jules stands, slings her guitar over her shoulder, and offers a hand. I take it. Her grip is strong. Real.

As we walk, I glance at my phone. 11%. I don’t check the screen. I don’t want to see the messages. The voicemails. The *names*.

But I think about Mom’s voice. Dad’s silence. The way my brother looked at me—like I’d betrayed him.

Jules glances at me. “You gonna be okay?”

I don’t know. I don’t know anything anymore.

But I say it anyway, because it’s the only thing that feels true right now:

“I don’t know. But I’m here. And for the first time in a long time… I’m *me*.”

Jules gives a small smile. “Then we’re already halfway there.”

The city hums around us—music, laughter, the distant wail of a siren. I don’t know what comes next. I don’t know if I’ll ever go back. But for now, I’m walking. And that’s enough.

For now.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the prompt’s structural demands: first-person, Taylor’s voice, one day in New Orleans, meets a runaway, internal monologue, mixed tense. It never strays from Taylor’s POV and keeps the clock running on “first day,” so instruction-adherence is solid.  
Where it falters is in the depth and specificity of that day. The city is sketched in generic tourist postcards—Frenchmen Street, fried food, saxophone, “jasmine or maybe rotting peaches”—rather than the humid, trash-sweet, copper-smelling, neon-flickering reality of July in New Orleans. We get no named café, no bar, no river smell, no streetcar clatter, no second-line echo, no dialect. Jules is introduced quickly, but the “warehouse cot” is a YA cliché borrowed from every runaway novel since 1995; we never see it, never learn who else is there, how they eat, where they pee, what the cops are like. The stakes feel literary rather than lived.

Taylor’s interior voice oscillates between authentic teen snark and workshop-y abstraction: “the city doesn’t let you disappear. It eats you. Or it changes you.” That line sounds like the back-cover blurb, not a 16-year-old’s raw thought at 2 p.m. when their stomach is caving in. The trans disclosure is repeated three times in almost the same words, each time told rather than shown through fresh sensory memory (the way Dad’s boot tapped, the way Mom’s coffee went cold). Likewise, Jules’ backstory is delivered in a single expository paragraph that begins “First time I hit the streets…”—pure tell, no show.

Dialogue is functional but exchanges feel like ping-pong Q&A designed to ferry plot facts: “You’re a runaway, then?” – “I don’t know how to do any of that.” – “Neither did I.” The rhythm is too clean; there’s no overlapping speech, no New Orleans cadence, no awkward pauses where teens actually talk. Jules’ voice is indistinguishable from Taylor’s interior monologue—same diction, same metaphors—so neither character gains separate weight.

Emotionally, the chapter lands on a forced uplift: “for the first time in a long time… I’m me.” That epiphany arrives after one conversation and a ten-block walk; it’s unearned. Taylor has not yet experienced a single concrete threat—no cop roust, no leering tourist, no hunger headache, no transphobic mis-gendering on the street—so the catharsis feels hollow. The battery drops 1% as a symbolic ticking clock, but nothing critical is lost when it hits zero, deflating tension.

Prose style is competent but repetitive: “I want to cry. I want to scream. I want to disappear” stacks three infinitives in a row; “I don’t know” appears five times. Metaphors are serviceable yet familiar (“loops like a broken record,” “the city hums around us”). There is no purple excess, but also no linguistic sparkle—no sentence that makes the reader pause and re-read. The whole chapter reads like a solid second draft that still needs granular research, sharper scene work, and braver emotional honesty.
